document.masterDocTitle: Finnish Pipunculidae (Diptera) studies Part I: Taxonomic notes on Cephalops Fallén, 1810, Pipunculus Latreille, 1802 and Tomosvaryella Aczél, 1939

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 93–99. Male genitalia of
Tomosvaryella kalevala
spec. nov.
93: syntergosternite 8 with surstyli and epandrium in dorsal view; 94 & 96: phallus in lateral and ventral view; 95: phallic guide in ventral view; 97: outer surstylus in lateral view; 98: inner surstylus in lateral view; 99: ejaculatory apodeme. Scale bars = 0.1mm.

FIGURES 100–104. 100: syntergosternite 8 with surstyli and epandrium in dorsal view of male
Tomosvaryella palliditarsis
, scale bar = 0.1mm; 101–102: ovipositor in lateral and dorsal view of female
Tomosvaryella minima
; 103–104: ovipositor in lateral and dorsal view of female
Tomosvaryella kalevala
spec. nov. Scale bars = 0.2mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology: The species epithet referrs to the Kalevala epos, a compilation of numerous traditional poems and songs from Finland , Russian Karelia and Ingria gathered and written down by Elias Lönnrot and others in the 19 th century. It represents a rich source of information on the life and beliefs of northern people in former times and is regarded as an important cultural heritage of this region.

Differential diagnosis: Male terminalia of
T. kalevala
spec. nov. is closest to
T. palliditarsis (Collin, 1931 )
but shows broader and shorter surstyli in strictly dorsal view (compare
Figs 93
&
100
). Other outer morphological features differentiating the two are the yellow postpronotal lobes (brown in
T. palliditarsis
) and eyes touching for length of ocellar triangle or 4–6 ommatidia ( 1.5 times length of ocellar triangle or 8–9 ommatidia in
T. palliditarsis
). Female
T. kalevala
spec. nov. stands closest to
T. minima
. In
T. kalevala
spec. nov. the base is slightly longer (lateral view) whereas the piercer is somewhat shorter (dorsal view) with stronger developed lateral flanges compared to
T. minima
, i.e. piercer as long as base in
T. kalevala
spec. nov. in contrast to piercer longer than base in
T. minima
(compare
Figs 101–102 & 103–104
).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 105–112. Surstyli in strictly dorsal and outer surstylus in lateral view of male
Tomosvaryella rossica
(105– 106) and male
Tomosvaryella cilitarsis
(109–110). Scale bars = 0.1mm. Ovipositor in lateral and dorsal view of female
Tomosvaryella rossica
(107–108) and
T. cilitarsis
(111–112). Scale bars = 0.2mm.

FIGURES 113–114. Scanning electron micrographs of left hind leg in anterior view of female
Tomosvaryella rossica
(113) and
Tomosvaryella cilitarsis
(114). Scale bars = 0.2mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Annotations :
Kuznetzov ( 1994 )
introduced numerous new species from the Palaearctic, their identity being difficult to understand because male genitalia are only illustrated in lateral view. Nevertheless,
T. kalevala
spec. nov. seems to be related to
T. tenuata
Kuznetzov, 1994
. Of the Japanese taxa described by Morakote et al . ( 1990 ), none seems to be closely allied to
T. kalevala
spec. nov.
